And since there's not a darn thing we mere mortals could do if it turns out he *is* malevolent and evil, then it seems like a moot point to me. Given that people are basing their lives on the dictates and whims of this God, I'd say it's far from moot! But that's just it--if he's God, he doesn't need to 'establish' any authority. He has it by default. His godhood is secure no matter if the mere mortals follow him or not. The sort of analogy where human leaders such as government officials, presidents, or kings DO lead by example (because they DO have to do that in order to secure authority) completely breaks down in such a case as this where we're talking about GOD and mere mortals who cannot possibly effect God. Again, the point is that God seems to want to mess with humans. He may be omnipotent, and omniscient, but he also seems to be incredibly caught up with what people on this rock think of him! Thus he needs to establish his authority over us. Look, if it helps you to think of God in such terms as you would a human leader, that's up to you. To me, that throws out the whole GODhood thing, so I think we're again back to different starting assumptions. (Though I'm not sure you really realize it.) We're not talking about a king that needs to pitch bread to the masses here. His Godhood is secure, regardless. So if he DOES pitch bread to the masses, it's all the more indicative that he doesn't have self-serving reasons for doing so. We are starting with different assumtions. You're starting with the belief that God is inherently good, where I'm not assuming benevolent intentions. You're again answering the question by saying we can't understand it, and if that's what you're happy with, then have fun. I'll carry on looking at the evidence. Have you considered that God might just 'pitch bread' because it amuses him? Have you also considered that God isn't chucking bread, he's just convinced some people that he did once? No, what I'm really saying here is that the concepts of benevolence and malevolence as you're using them can't really be attributed when you're talking about something on the order of what we're talking about: GOD. Because you're completely ignoring the 1000 lb elephant of said GOD's omniscience. You're making a judgment ignoring what could very well be the most important factor of all, and therefore it's actually you who is avoiding something here because you don't want to possibly attribute benevolence to the Judeo-Christian God. I'd like a God figure to be benevolent, because the consequences of a malicious entity with that sort of power are terrifying. However, as I've said before omniscience does not mean that you're a good guy. I'm not ignoring the fact he knows all, I'm saying it's irrelevant to God's nature. Unless you're trying to state that all the massacres that God has commited (or caused) are a good thing because God knew what would happen in the future... Plus, I think your comments here are an over-simplification in light of theology. In my opinion someone can look at the same scriptures and come away with different conclusions than you are when taking them as a whole--indeed that's exactly WHY some believe God is good as opposed to evil. Those scriptures indicate that God has offered a way to AVOID the eternal consequences for evil: not exactly something an evil and malevolent God would do. Your point? Plenty of people read the scriptures and come away with a negative view of God. A benevolent God wouldn't have created hell in the first place. What you describe there is a God who sits in the corner and giggles at the tricks he forces his creations to perform in order to gain his favour. I don't really think he does. Where in the scriptural texts of the Judeo-Christian God does he get all bend out of shape over people not accepting him? Does Hell ring any bells? But I find it interesting that you ask that question; if he gets bent out of shape that someone won't accept him, then that would indicate (to some extent at least) he DOES want our acceptance, and therefore does care about us. Doesn't exactly fit your idea of the malevolent vindictive God. Wanting acceptance again does not mean benevolence. Charles Manson probably wanted acceptance from his peers, but that doesn't make him benevolent. Personally I would suggest that for an omnipotent being to spend all his time worrying about the actions of some big brained apes on this particular rock is a bit pathetic. And please stop trying to attribute my views to me. I'm arguing over the evidence, not over a personal crusade.

Does the owner of an ant farm know or care how individual ants behave or think? This would approximate the relationship between a god and it's believers, yet the believers cling desperately to the notion that they matter to it.
